subsection.title: Intuition for probability definitions
subsection.p: When we say game of chance or chance process, we imagine some kind of orderly procedure (for example: flipping coins, rolling dice, drawing lottery tickets, etc.) that produces an outcome that we cannot predict with certainty. In the face of uncertainty, we do the next best thing, which is to assign likelihood. For example, we don't know for certain in advance whether a roll of a fair die will land showing the 6 face, or whether the die will land showing a face with an even or an odd number. But we can predict that the 6 face outcome will occur in about 1/6\approx 16.7\% of many rolls, and that a roll will show a face with an odd number in about half of many rolls. This is what we mean when we say the probability that a roll of a fair die comes up 6 is 1/6, and the probability that a fair dies comes up odd is 1/2.

This simple example introduces the three components of the mathematical definition of probability. For a roll of a fair die, there is a set of outcomes \Omega=\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}. Subsets of \Omega are called events. For example, the sets A=\{6\} and B=\{1,3,5\} the events described in words by A=\text{"roll a 6"} and B=\text{"roll an odd number"}, respectively. The probabilities P(A)=1/6 and P(B)=1/2 are assignments given to events by a function P called a probability measure. The subsection that follow give the complete formal definition of a probability space.

subsection.title: Algebras of sets
subsection.p: We begin with some definitions from set theory.

definition.title: Power set of a set
definition.p: Let X be a set. The power set of X, denoted \mathcal{P}(X), is the set of all subsets of X. In symbols, \mathcal{P}(X) = \{A\colon A\subseteq X\}.

subsection.title: Probability Spaces
subsection.p: disclaimer needed, some comment about finite versus infinite outcome spaces

definition.p:
A finite probability space is a triple (\Omega,\mathcal{E},P), where \Omega is a set, \mathcal{E} is a finite algebra of subsets of \Omega, and P is a function P\colon \mathcal{E}\to [0,1] that satisfies the following properties.
P(\Omega)=1
\text{if }A,B \in \mathcal{E}\text{ and } A\cap B=\emptyset, \text { then } P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B)
Elements of \Omega are called outcomes. Elements of \mathcal{E} are called events, and P is called a probability measure.
